title: How many total confirmed cases of COVID-19 will the World Health Organization (WHO) report for Brazil as of 12 November 2021?
possible_answers: More than 24 million but fewer than 26 million
preds: As of November 8, 2021 there are 21.89 million cases according to @Our World in Data
Holding out a tiny bit from going higher in case there's a data dump in the next few days
Adjusting forecast for declining rates and vanishing timescale
It has stabilized around 80K per week; this will put the cases about 300K shy of 22 million.
In order to go over 22 Million, Brazil would have to have over 170,000 cases in 10 days, which seems very unlikely when looking at the pattern of the last five weeks.
The last two recorded week of 10/18 and 10/25 had between 80-85K cases. With a current 21,821,124 cases. It that rate keeps up, it will still remain under 22 million by 11/12, but it will be close.

Slowing but steady trend downward. Possibility that there was a large volume of delayed reporting  posted on Sept 20th (and July 25th). Only a small probability in the upcoming 10 days of a 100% increase in reported cases + a update of delayed reporting.
Leaving a 1% chance of a data dump.
21,810,855 as of Nov 2. 7 day 11,305. 10 Days to go, avg needs to be nearly 19k to go over 22m now, so barring a drastic change this one looks done.

I am truly surprised that there hasn't been a large Delta wave yet. It's not clear to me that changes in case reporting rules explain most of why cases remain low. There is also a Delta sublineage that may not always be detected by PCR tests and is circulating in at least some locations. Beyond that, it truly makes no sense whatsoever to me that a Delta surge hasn't happened, and I can only surmise that the virus had already made its way through most of the population by the time Delta became dominant, and also, the main respiratory virus season has passed. I hope that Brazil will not see a Delta wave, but I do wonder whether they may simply see a slow one play out over time.
The average would need to be >17k/day for the remainder of the forecast for bin 2 to be reached. I don't think that's possible at this point.
Brier score destruction!

I believe reporting issues, primarily related to the government having changed case definitions, will likely keep cases in bin 1 at this point. That likely doesn't fully explain why Brazil hasn't had a larger Delta wave, though. At least one Delta sublineage is not picked up well by local PCR tests. Perhaps for many reasons, including seasonality, a Delta wave in Brazil will be lower and more prolonged.

Odds of another ‘correction’ adding more than 60k cases before the deadline: 30%? 
Odds of reaching 22M without this happening: 15%

21,766,168 as of Oct 29. 7 day avg 12,014 and steady. 14 days left means current trend is to 21.93m. would have to be over 16.7k/day to go over. A 35% jump seems unlikely but not impossible so I'm sticking with 80% chance it'll be under and hoping they don't change counting protocols again...

We're at 21.78 million cases with 14 days left, so we'd need about 15,700 cases a day for this to get above 22 million, and case rates have been remaining steadily below that over the last 20 days. While the delta strain has now hit Brazil, the population-wide immunity is already quite high because of so many previous cases before Delta hit. I'm leaving about a 1/3 chance that cases start creeping upwards to hit 22 million by Nov 12th.

"Brazil: “The Municipality of Belém, through Sesma, warns that a Delta subvariant (AY.33), which is already circulating in Belém, may not be detected by rapid tests and by standard RT-qPCR protocols, and that anyone with symptoms compatible with COVID-19+.”"
https://twitter.com/LauraMiers/status/1452498471353831425
I'd be closer to 80% on bin 1 if not for the risk of a data dump in the coming days.

Oct, 25 18 Days* today´s 7 days average (13000!!!) = 21.945.000 / need 16000 or lower to be fewer than 22 million / Current pace 22 M at Nov, 15
It will be close!

21.94-22.06M 
Looks like it’s going right to the wire, but I’m still expecting some sort of correction before the close
Must have pressed submit without realising. Unintended.

20 days left in the forecast. Need an average of 14k/day to reach 22M. Brazil is at 12k/day. We can be pretty sure the level won't stay constant, and there has not yet been a Delta wave. A data dump is also fairly likely in the remainder of the forecast period. I do think bin 2 is extremely likely.

21,680,480 as of Oct.22. 7-Day avg 12,052. 21 Days to go. 7 day needs to be under 15.2k which it hasn't topped for 3 weeks now. It's a squeaker and a data dump certainly can't be ruled out. The current trend seems relatively established and variables such as Delta should be fully entrenched. I'm tempted to go higher on raw numbers but will resist a bit longer since its still looking very close.

Forecast back to 21.88M with yesterday's data. Only 22 data points missing. I'd be higher in bin 1 if not for the pattern of large data dumps in the third week of each month. The good news is that we should have a lot more clarity by the end of next week.
Forecast increased to 21.9 and adjusting accordingly.

I'm still leaning towards total cases tipping over 22M, but only with another additional 'correction' of 90-150k cases in the next few weeks. Since the unnatural drop in reported cases from 6th September, it has been hard to fully trust what's going on: trying to understand this better all I can find from Reuters (and elsewhere) is that changes to reporting were made recently due to "new demands from the federal Health Ministry regarding case counting, the details of which were not revealed." (article from 5th October)
https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/brazil-reports-over-150000-covid-19-cases-one-day-amid-rio-backlog-2021-09-19/
Reading between the lines the corrections may have been a one-off as a consequence of this, and future cases may not be reported as readily. 
Delta has clearly been prevalent in at least the majority of eastern states for many weeks now, but this this hasn't affected case trends as expected to date:
https://outbreak.info/location-reports?xmin=2021-07-01&xmax=2021-10-21&loc=BRA
And to add further doubts, last week Brazil's Federal Council of Medicine (CFM) was sued for approving the use of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine last year, in connection with a whistle-blower report on one of Brazil's biggest healthcare providers covering up coronavirus deaths:
https://brazilian.report/liveblog/coronavirus/
https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2021/sep/29/brazil-prevent-senior-hospital-chain-covid-accusations
As the outcome is determined using WHO data, I am less convinced 22M will be seen by the close.

I'll have to keep gradually winding down this position every few days until or unless another correction appears - otherwise the data suggests that we'll finish just under 22M. I still expect another backlog of 100-150k cases to be added, but accept it may not happen before the close of the question.

I'm still expecting 20-20.2M but heavily dependant on a backlog 'correction' to bring figures up to date.
I'm aware that the chance of this happening before the end date is not that high, so I have to accept that at the close of the question the number could still be under 22M. TBH it's become a gamble as to whether a backlog will suddenly be added to the tally or not ...

21,597,949 as of Oct 15. 28 days to go. 7 day avg is 11,383.  Needs to be under 14.3k/day to be under 22M. This is going to be close.... but the data now says under so that's the way I'm going, until the next data bomb that is....
Forecast is now coming in at 21.86M
My forecast is coming in at 21.95M, but the chances of another data correction seem reasonably high. Staying on the uncertain side for now.

21.59M total cases to 12th October, and Brazil has now reached a historic low of  13,003k  cases per 7-day average, below the rate needed to reach 22M by the deadline. But there is evidence that officially reported cases and deaths are not being updated regularly, or in some cases perhaps just not reported.
So my forecast is now heavily dependant on another correction/backlog of cases being taken into account by 12 November (which may or may not happen frankly). 
I'm still at 20-20.2M or thereabouts, but will have to see if São Paolo and Rio in particular show any jumps in numbers over the next couple of weeks.

There have been 21.5 million cases of Covid in Brazil, 600,000 deaths, and 235,00 vaccinated up to the beginning of October 2021.  I feel like Covid can be a tricky one to predict.  Cases and deaths seemed to spike during the summer months, perhaps because people want to be outside, and it could possibly spread due to people being in close proximity.  I think it could it cases could reduce as time goes on due to vaccine roll outs. 
https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br

It will be close!

Today´s trend - low
Delta variant does not seams to be an factor

As of 8 October 2021 there are 21,516,967 confirmed cases of COVID-19. 
The population of Brazil is about 212.6 million. According to the New York Times, the current daily average is 13,088 cases per day, which is a 31% decrease from the daily average in late September. If the daily rate of COVID-19 remains the same through 12 November 2021 that will add an additional 458,080 cases to the count. To reach a total caseload of 22 million, there will need to be 483,033 additional cases. Even though the rate of daily cases is decreasing, it will be cutting it close to the 22 million mark. Therefore, I believe the number of cases as of 11/12/2021 will be just above 22 million, but almost certainly not above 24 million. 
References:
https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/world/brazil-covid-cases.html

As of the writing of this prediction, the current number of coronavirus infections in Brazil stands at 21,516, 967 as per Reuters (2021) and states the average new infection ate as 16,774 per day, which if it remains constant would place the number of infections at 22,104, 057 as of November 12th, narrowly passing the threshold for “between 22 million and 24 million”. In order to pass the benchmark of 24,000,000 and reach the next level of prediction, the average number of daily cases would have to immediately increase to 70,498, an increase of 53,724 (420%) and maintain that level throughout the next month. Based on this information, I would place my confidence at 
90% that the number remains between 22 and 24 million with a 10% holdout that it could remain below 22 million if Brazil undertakes and sustains a sufficient level of transmission management.. It is far more likely that the number of new daily cases plateaus or even reduces, which is why I have assigned the small possibility (10%) that the number will not reach 22 million. Analyzing data directly from the World Health Organization (WHO) seems to back up the conclusion that new cases, overall, have been decreasing week by week, with the highest rate of week-to-week growth being September 20th at 142, 028 cases (WHO, 2021). Although this also happens to be the highest single week growth rate going back to the start of the pandemic, this information further corroborates my assertion that the likeliest outcome is the number of coronavirus cases in Brazil reaching a level of at least 22 million but fewer than 24 million.  References: Reuters. (2021). Reuters Covid-19 Tracker. https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-and-maps/countries-and-territories/brazil/. World Health Organization. (2021). WHO Health Emergency Dashboard: WHO (COVID-19) Homepage. https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br.

This forecast was made on 10/5/21 at approximately 3:30P.M., U.S. central time. As of Oct 5, the current number of total confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Brazil sits at approximately 21.5million with +10,425 cases. I believe there to be an 80% chance probability that Brazil will reach an excess of 22million confirmed cases as of 12 November 21 with a 20% chance probability that it will not. I believe in an 80% probability of it being 22million based on current projections. While Brazil has seen the surge come to a slow as of September 13, there was a sharp spike in cases between 9/18 and 9/24. While the numbers again dropped off, there is still plenty of time left during the month of October for there to be yet another dramatic spike given the unpredictability of the virus in the shape of different and sudden variants. Also taken into consideration, is that people in Brazil may become complacent with a drop such as the one shown and disregard the short but sharp rise in mid-September and choose to spend more time with family or friends as a result. With this sudden exposure, there may be yet another spike to carry the numbers north of 22 million. There is also the issue of halting the use of China company SINOVAC’s vaccine as health concerns grow over its use. Allegedly, a 16-year died as a result of the vaccination causing a panic. Whether or not local health officials will allow this to deter the use of what appears to be Brazil’s only means to a vaccine or if public fears will sway those yet to receive the shot, remains uncertain. If this does cause a drop off to immunizations, then I believe that there will be an excess of 22 million cases in Brazil before or on 11/12. As for the 20% speculation that it will reach and or surpass 22million, there is always uncertainty. As of today, numbers show that cases are still dropping despite the sudden and high spike in September. So, if Brazil can manage to stay on its current trajectory while taking the necessary precautions and continued vaccinations then it may very well avoid eclipsing 22 million by 11/12.

As of 10/10/21, Brazil has 21,516,967 confirmed cases. That's 483,033 cases away from the 22million threshold. With 33 days remaining between now and 11/12/21 the rates only need to average 14,637 cases/day. The WHO website shows covid infections trending downward so far; however, there is an uptick in cases towards the tail end of September and October is showing signs of being able to hover above 14,637/day as an average. This will likely tip the scales over the 22 million mark. That said, I find it very unlikely to add 2.6million cases in 33 days.

21,516,967 as of Oct 8. 7 day avg is 15,438 and flat. 35 days to go as of last data. Needs to be under 13.8k to be under 22. 72.5% 1 dose, 46.4% 2. Still possible to be under 22 but not the most likely scenario so nudging 4% from bin 1 to bin 2.

On 20 September 2021, Reuters explained, “Brazil reported some 150,106 additional COVID-19 cases, according to data released by the nation’s Health Ministry, an unusually larger number due to what officials said was an adjustment in how case numbers are tabulated” (2021). As of 7 October 2021, the World Health Organization (WHO) reported 10,425 new cases in the last 24 hours and 21,478,546 cumulative cases. As of 10 October 2021, the WHO reported 17,893 new cases in the last 24 hours, with 21,516,967 cumulative cases (2021). The WHO also reported that as of 1 October 2021, 225,795,545 vaccine doses have been administered. Although there was an increase in the number of confirmed cases from 7 October to 10 October, the daily confirmed cases should decrease with preventive measures and the number of vaccines administered. Therefore, the total confirmed cases of COVID-19 the WHO will report for Brazil as of 12 November 2021 would likely be between 22 million and 24 million, inclusive (75%) (low-moderate-confidence), more than 24 million but fewer than 26 million (23%) (low-confidence), and between 26 million and 28 million, inclusive (2%) (low-confidence). Due to recent issues in counting and formulating the correct number of COVID-19 cases in Brazil, this forecast's confidence level remains low.   Resources:
https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br
https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/brazil-reports-over-150000-covid-19-cases-one-day-amid-rio-backlog-2021-09-19/

So I think this was one of the easiest questions to Fermi-ize. Cases will depend on the ratio of vaccinated to unvaccinated Brazilians: greater vaccinations will reduce the rate of spread, and thus the rate of increase in confirmed cases. Yes there are some other political variables to consider, such as institutional trust. But I think this is a solid starting point.  As of October 8, Brazil had 21.6 million confirmed cases and 72.5% of the population received at least one does, which is approximately 90% effective against transmission, so adjust that to 65.25%. Brazil has a total population of 212 million people. The CDC also estimates that true Covid numbers are at least 6 times higher than confirmed cases. So approximately 125 million people (59% of the population) already have natural immunity, while 138 million (adjusted) have vaccinated immunity. Yet there is inevitably some overlap. I'm a little rusty on my probability calculations, but I think this would be P (A U B) --> P (62.5% U 59%) --> P =84.6% of the population with some form of immunity. That breaks down to approximately 178 million Brazilians with little to no chance of contracting Covid, leaving 34 million susceptible. Divide that by the original 6, which shows only about 560,000 more infections are likely to be confirmed.  Of course reinfection sometimes occurs, and as testing continues to expand the ratio of detected/undetected cases will decrease. But this would more likely be in the long term. This sets an upper bound of about 22.2 million of total possible confirmed cases, leaving only two possible choices.  If Brazil stays at its current average of about 15,000 cases a day, that puts the upper bound at 495,000 cases by Nov 12, right above the 22 million mark. While this is likely to decline as vaccinations and natural immunity increase, there is a diminishing rate of vaccinations- only a 1% increase over the past two weeks. This is likely to slow further as most who want the vaccine already got it. Thus new vaccinations probably won't be enough to bring the projection below the 22 million mark.  But it will be close!

Judging by the COVID rates from the past 24hrs, it does not seem likely the COVID cases will skyrocket past 26 million. The 30% chance represents any successful efforts by both the Brazilian government and populace to minimize COVID exposure. However, given it's past history with handling of COVID, this is not a great chance of seeing such a result.

As of October 7, 2021 WHO reports a total of 21,499,074 confirmed cases. There are 35 days remaining until November 12, 2021 and there would need to an additional 500,926 cases to reach the 22 million mark. Over the last 24 hours (October 7) WHO reports 20,528 new cases. Over the last 7 days there have been a total of 117,284 new confirmed cases, the average of those 7 days is 16,755 cases. It appears that Brazil will pass the 22 million mark but less than 24 million as of November 12, 2021

Firstly, WHO records Brazil’s COVID-19 confirmed case totals with a weekly aggregated report.  From the last report on Oct 1 the totals were from the week of 20 September to 27 September, so the numbers to be reported on 12 November will be the totals of the week ending on November 8, as each report on the Friday is of the week previous from that Monday back one week.  November 8 is exactly one month from today and at a significantly decreasing rate of reported contractions in a country of 212.6million (2020) people the total of confirmed is roughly 10% with first reporting numbers occurring March 16 of 2020, approximately 17months for 10% of the population and one month left to record and though underreporting is possible the population of Brazil is roughly 88%urban.  With 17months recorded exposure, 10% confirmed at 21.2million and an 88% urban population it is unlikely a massive increase will occur in the next month to impact the total number of cases, especially based on current regressions according to the WHO. The average weekly total increase for August and September was at 175,871.5 with an average .85% Weekly Rate of Change.  At 175,871.5 x 4 weeks is 703,486 which collectively could easily put it over the  483,033 needed to exceed 22,000,000 for option number one at 120.7k needed each week to reach the goal and new variants dominating the medicalscape of COVID-19 currently in a country of roughly 180million people in populated centers this seems highly possible. Brazil has struggled with the gamma variant as well and has a national government not concerned with prevention methods, a schedule to allow cruise ships to return to service 01Nov,  and porous border practices all indicate the weekly amount to exceed 120k as highly likely especially as the effectiveness of vaccines to reduce spread or repeat contraction of COVID-19 are in dispute demonstrating a considerable risk of reinfection of even vaccinated persons.   Considering all these factors I then proposed the percentage rates proposed in the questionnaire. https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.RUR.TOTL.ZS?locations=BR
https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br
https://www.cnn.com/travel/article/brazil-travel-covid-19/index.html
https://www.statnews.com/2021/08/24/as-delta-spread-covid-19-vaccine-effectiveness-against-infection-fell-from-90-to-66-in-one-key-study/

"In Brazil, from 3 January 2020 to 6:49pm CEST, 8 October 2021, there have been 21,516,967 confirmed cases of COVID-19 with 599,359 deaths, reported to WHO. As of 1 October 2021, a total of 225,795,545vaccine doses have been administered."
It does seem that roughly confirmed cases with an average of 15-35k cases confirmed a day, I have no doubt they will easily hit over 22 million cases, but the slight chance it will be boarder line slightly under 22 million at the same time.  https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br

WHO data shows that the number of daily confirmed cases is on a steep decline, falling from a weekly rate of 152,154 the week of August 30th to 131,501 the week of September 30th, with intervening dips as low as 105,369 the week of September 13th. At the same time, “Our World in Data” (https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?facet=none&Metric=People+vaccinated&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=true&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~BRA) shows that vaccination rates are high, likely contributing to the decline in cases. From August 30th to September 30th the vaccination rate climbed from 62.86% to 70.63%, representing over 17 million people vaccinated in a month. The most relevant GJP interval is “Fewer than 22 million” and current case volume is 21,499,074, an increase of 524,224 over September 6th’s volume of 20,974,850. The operative question, then, is whether I forecast that from today, October 8 to a month from now, November 12, case volume will increase by another 500,000 to break the 22 million mark. There are 36 days from October 7th (most recent data available) to November 12th. At a low case count of 10k/day there will be 360,000 added cases. At a medium case count of 15k/day there will be 540,000 incremental cases, putting us over the 22 million mark. To stay below 22 million daily average case count would need to remain below 13,889 over those 36 days. The most recent complete week, September 27th, averaged 18,785 daily cases. As such, I think it is fairly likely (70%) that Brazil will break the 2M case mark prior to 12 November.

With there being 21.5 million total confirmed cases with an average of 10-30k cases confirmed a day meaning 70-210k cases a week  and roughly 5 weeks left till November 12th it’s a safe bet we should see around 23 million cases by November 12th. There is a possibility with vaccinations the number steadily decline or a large outbreak happening but doubtful it’ll force the numbers out of that 22 to 24 million case zone.  Source https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=BRA

Reason: According to the World Health Organization Brazil has had 21,499,974 cases of Covid 19 since January of 2020. The last data point given on their website was a total weekly confirmed case count of 131,501 people on the week of September 27th. Given that statistic it is likely that the case count will exceed 22 million cases by the closing date of November 12th, which is about 5 weeks away. It is important to note that the case numbers are decreasing, according to the New York Times it is at a rate of 60% from the average two weeks ago. Even with a drop in case numbers the current reported cases is close enough to 22 million that  a decrease in cases per week would have to be pretty substantial to keep the number of cases from going over into the next category.  Sources:  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/world/brazil-covid-cases.html (Links to an external site.) https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br

Per the data received from the WHO, it seems like COVID cases are slowly decreasing besides the week of Sep 20th, which sharply increased but cases fell again. Its highly likely that cases will push above 22 million because its already at 21.5 million as of Oct 7th and by Nov 12th it will be slightly over 22 million. This is the case because even with the decline there is around 110k cases on average per week. With five weeks left till Nov 12th, the additional cases will be close to 550k. 
Sources
https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br
https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-and-maps/countries-and-territories/brazil/
Reducing confidence in bin 2 slightly, reporting seems to be all over the place frankly. Backlog likely and cases reported fluctuating for the coming weeks.

Forecast as of 06OCT21: The overall cases in Brazil seem to be plateauing with an average rate of 13,000 new cases a day. With 36 days left in this forecast that would put the number under 22 million. This also with the publics acceptance of becoming vaccinated should actually push the daily average down, making it probable to keep the number under 22 million cases by 12 November 2021. The one thing that could change this forecast is whether or not a new variant is discovered pushing the numbers of even those vaccinated back up.  Sources: https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/brazil/ https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br https://ycharts.com/indicators/brazil_coronavirus_vaccination_rate_any_dosage https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/south-america-where-lambda-and-mu-variants-broke-out-sees-covid-cases-plummet/ar-AAOaMvl https://www.deseret.com/coronavirus/2021/8/17/22628695/new-covid-variant-south-america-israel-lockdown

21,468,121 as of Oct 5. 7 day avg is 16,022. 39 days left means average needs to be under 13,637. The trend is still generally down outside of the corrections. 71.6% of the total population has one vaccine dose, 44.2% have two. Most major cities have introduced a vaccine passport (of some sort... https://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/nosubscription/vaccine-passport-in-brazil-where-is-it-mandatory/). This question is going to be close; unless we get another surprise adjustment that is...

If Brazil has the same number of confirmed cases in October as it did in September, it just barely exceed 22 million (22,071,178), While there was a spike in week three of September, it dropped significantly in week four, almost to week one and two levels. Even if it remained at the levels of week four, the number would remain just under 22 million (21,994,125).

21.46M cases, and 7-day average of 16k/day, with 14k/day needed to exceed 22M by the deadline.
Most of the uncertainty now looks to lie with the reporting: significant tranches of cases have been added in the last 30 days, particularly Rio (120k+) and São Paolo (47k+), around otherwise unusually low daily numbers. Another big correction would almost certainly tip the balance, but with backlogs appearing to be added sporadically there's no certainty within the deadline. And now there's news of hospital-backed cover ups * sigh *  this may have to play out for a while yet.

WHO is reporting as of 10/01/2021 21,399,546 confirmed cases. As of 10/01/2021 the rolling 7 day average was 16,862 confirmed cases. Brazil has administered at least 237,425,768 doses of vaccine so far. Assuming every person receives 2 doses of vaccine, that's enough to have vaccinated roughly 56% of the population, or about 120,516,365 individuals. Brazil is reporting that this past week, approximately 1,375,916 doses of vaccine were administered. At that rate, it will be 31 more days to vaccinate another 10% of the population or about 21,444,193 individuals. By the end of October a potential 141,960,558 could be vaccinated or 66% of the population. That would leave 72,481,373 unvaccinated. Between now and November 12th, if there are an additional 15,000 new cases daily, this will represent a total of 22,029,546 confirmed cases. If the daily cases spike with the onset of Spring, then using the new cases for September 30th, the total would be 22,145,298 confirmed cases.

It appears that Brazil will pass the 22 million mark but less than 24 million as of November 12, 2021

The New York Times reported that Brazil's COVID infection rate has increased roughly 62% in the last two weeks. Looking at their COVID map, 15,000 infections a day seemed like one of the lowest points. With it currently being September 19th, there are roughly 54 days remaining until November 12th. I took the minimum daily infection rate of 15,000 and multiplied it by 54 days, bringing the total infection numbers to 810,000. When adding that to the already 21,230,325 million people infected, it brings the rate to 22,040,325 million people. If I go with the current daily average of 34,452 and multiply it by 54 days, it brings the total of 1,860,408 million people infected. If I add that 54 day total to the already 21,230,325 million people infected, it brings the grand total to 23,090,733 million people infected by November 12,2021. With the Delta-Variant surging in most of the world, it would not surprise me if it goes above my prediction.
The Delta wave is finally starting.

There's been a spike in reported cases (see @paulm 's comment https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1334876) so the total is at ~21.2M now (WHO website hasn't updated with the recent increase). 7 day avg was 15k and sliding prior to the spike. At current average that puts it at almost exactly 22M... If the 7 day avg slides even a little bit more it'll be under, which I'm skeptical of. If there's another spike in reporting it'll almost certainly be over. Looks like this one is coming down to the wire so with the new data I'm moving back to better odds of it being over.

Very interesting reporting coming out of key Brazilian states:
São Paolo recorded over 25,000 cases yesterday (roughly five times the moving average two weeks ago)
Rio de Janeiro recorded 105,000 cases yesterday 
These states are significant not just because they contribute a high proportion of overall cases (~40%), but also because they have a high recorded prevalence of Delta (admittedly from very small sampling data). Collectively they have added over 150K cases in the past week; ten times the moving average for the whole of Brazil. This may be anomalous, based on back-reporting to catch up on oddly low recent accounts over last week, but shows that this is still open, moving the recent average closer to an expected 18K/day. Given that, I still think the final total could reach 21.1-21.4M.

What is going on here? Not only is <22M possible, it is starting to look likely, and that doesn't quite stack up to me. Over 90% of recent sequenced cases in São Paolo are Delta, and yet the case numbers are still falling rapidly. Immunity from prior exposure is admittedly very high, and in combination with even a single vaccination dose will create a big defence, but restrictions have been dropped since the beginning of August, and anecdotally restaurants and businesses are busy with unmasked staff and customers. So unless children are being kept indoors or everyone is avoiding everyone else, I don't quite get it. 
Or maybe everyone has had Covid already, as others have also considered? 
I suppose the Independence day holiday on Sep 7th may have created a false impression of reduced cases over the last two days, but if case numbers don't rise this week then sub-22m will look like an evens bet.

Case of hold nerve, we now know breakthrough cases are not (sadly) really uncommon and delta variant will arrive and cases will increase. That said, not impossible for first bin, but it would have to go against the above.
It's mysterious to me why Brazil's Delta wave hasn't started yet.

"Brazil's federal health regulator Anvisa on Saturday suspended the use of over 12 million doses of a COVID-19 vaccine developed by China's Sinovac Biotech Ltd that were produced in an unauthorized plant, it said in a statement." https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/brazil-suspends-use-of-12-million-shots-of-china-s-sinovac-covid-19-vaccine-1.5574802 Of interest:

20.7M as of Aug 27. 7 day avg ~25k/day and slowly dropping. 77 days to go. 63% have one dose, 28% have 2.  7 day avg needs to be under 16.7k to be under 22M. Under 47k to be under 24 (which is a virtual certainty at this point). The 7-day avg is dropping by ~2.5k/week, but its uncertain how long this trend can sustain as delta becomes prevalent. Of concern: "Covid admissions in Rio jump 63% in one month; state returns to record more than 200 deaths in 24 hours" https://g1.globo.com/rj/rio-de-janeiro/noticia/2021/08/24/internacoes-por-covid-no-rio-saltam-63percent-em-um-mes-estado-volta-a-registrar-mais-de-200-mortes-em-24-horas.ghtml Interestingly: "[A] study found that fully vaccinated but uninfected people were significantly more likely to get infected than people who had previously been infected and recovered from the disease."
"The study, conducted in one of the most highly Covid-19–vaccinated countries in the world, examined the medical records of tens of thousands of Israelis, charting their infections, symptoms, and hospitalizations between 1 June and 14 August, when the Delta variant predominated in Israel."
 https://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/modern-day-censorship/eye-opening-scientific-study-from-israel-shows-natural-immunity-superior-to-covid-vaccine-in-delta-variant/ It looks like ~25% of brazil population has antibodies from serology testing:  https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Monthly-antibody-prevalence-and-signal-to-cutoff-S-C-reading-in-Manaus-and-Sao-Paulo_fig1_345330174 If brazil has higher natural immunity than most countries, and natural immunity is superior to vaccination against delta, and their vaccination program keeps steady pace, this could be a closer question than it looks. That said, the current downward trend would have to continue virtually uninterupted for the next 2 months to be below 22M, which seems unlikely. I now think the crowd is looking good on this one and the total will most likely be in the 22.2 - 22.4 range on Nov. 12 but will have to check how the trend is looking in a couple weeks.

From 6/30 to 7/10, cases declined by 0.86k/day. From 8/11 to 8/21, cases declined by 0.17k/day. At this rate of decline of the decline, cases should stop declining within ~2 weeks. At that point, the growth in Delta cases will balance out the decline in non-Delta cases. But because case levels are so high, we know that Delta cases will already be growing quickly, more quickly than non-Delta cases are falling. So we can expect cases to start growing very soon after cases stop falling, in contrast with the long plateaus seen in the UK and the US. And then we will see how fast a Delta wave grows and how big it gets in Brazil. There is huge uncertainty because we really don't know what levels of existing immunity there are, but I do think the Delta wave will be substantial. Here's an example of just how different Delta waves can be in individual communities because of different levels of previous spread: https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1429141726266990597 Broadening the forecast more between bins 2 and 3 because, looking at previous case data in Brazil, I am reminded that it can be very, very noisy. For example, suppose that cases stop growing around the end of August and start growing in early September, with just over 2 months left to the forecast. Case growth from similar levels last fall, around Nov. 12, added >4.5M in just over 2 months. Update 8/24: Brazil's CFR is 1.69x the US CFR, suggesting that 59% of the proportion of cases the US detects are detected in Brazil. Brazil's population is 64% of that of the US. So, 30k cases/day in Brazil would correspond to something like 28k cases/day in Brazil. The Delta wave in the US started when cases were ~12k/day. By the time cases were 28k/day (July 16), cases were increasing quickly. I think we can anticipate an upturn in cases within a week or so in Brazil. Cases will grow slowly for a while, as non Delta cases continue to fall, but case growth will then accelerate.

Cases/day declined from 55k on June 30 to 35k on July 30 (0.67k/day), and from there to 30k on Aug. 18 (0.26k/day). Although there is considerable uncertainty in the current rate of decline (it could be closer to 0.47k/day), it's clear that the decline is slowing and that the Delta wave is approaching. 3.5 weeks ago, I thought we'd likely be seeing cases starting to rise by now, but instead, it looks like maybe cases will start rising within the next 2 to 4 weeks.  We may see an abrupt transition from decline to rise. In the UK, cases were already low and almost plateaued when Delta emerged. If we think of the case curve as the sum of 2 separate curves, Delta and non-Delta, then in the UK, the Delta curve was somewhat to the right (in time) of a full decline in non-Delta cases. The same was true in the US. I suspect that in Brazil, the 2 curves are going to be squished closer together. Delta is coming up in numbers and percentage while non-Delta cases are still in fairly steep decline. I suspect that at some point over the next few weeks, there's going to be a comparatively sudden turnaround, at which point Delta will already be going strong enough to have made up for ongoing declines in non-Delta cases; in other words, the starting point for the Delta wave in Brazil will appear to be much higher than it was in the US or the UK. In other words, if Brazil's non-Delta cases were really low now as they were in the UK and the US just before their Delta waves, I suspect we might all be saying that the Delta wave has already started or is about to start. When the Delta wave will *appear* to start in Brazil (meaning that we see total cases start to go up), how fast cases will rise, and how high the peak will be are still the open questions, to my mind. If we suppose that cases start increasing in early September, then we will essentially see 2 months of a Delta wave for the remainder of this question. As of right now, Brazil is at 20.46M cases. By the time cases start to increase, the total may be around 21M. I would expect a Delta wave to add 1.5M to <3M in the forecast period, for a total firmly in bin 2, shockingly in line with the crowd.

As of Aug 3, Brazil would need to 20.4k/day to reach 22M, 40k/day to reach 24M, 59.6k per day to reach 26M and 79.2k to reach 28M. Brazil has spent the last 6 months hovering between 40k and 80k cases daily. 20% full vaccination rate is not really significant (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations), but Brazil has significant people with antibodies in their blood stream. Brazil's rates continued to decline since Aug 3. The current decline, if continued, would be 21.4m on decision day. However, Brazil still has its history of being between 40k and 80k. Today's rate of around 29k per day, would put them on track for between 22 and 24m. So I'm reducing % from 26 and 28m, adding % to 22-24m. I really don't think the decline will keep up forever, and it only takes Brazil being normal to put it into 22-24m or 24-26m.
I think cases in states of São Paolo and Rio may be starting to rise soon, which could be a precursor to the decline in case numbers across Brazil slowing to a plateau.
Realised that I could paste my first forecast for this and it would still fit, with lower and upper limits, so edging towards higher confiidence.

The decline continues, longer than I would have thought. We may not see an increase in cases, as Brazil's Delta wave starts, for another month. 20.25M now. Suppose 21.0M by Sept. 12. Then 3M cases could be added in the following 2 months, just as 3M cases were added between June 11 and August 11. That would take Brazil to exactly 24M. If a Delta wave is steeper and/or higher or starts sooner, the total will be >24M. If it's not as steep, is shorter, or starts later, it will be <24M. I'm going to zero out bin 4 for now because I don't think that's plausible right now. But I don't think there's enough information to know whether we'll end up in bin 2 or bin 3. I'll weight bin 2 higher than bin 3 just because the Delta wave could start later than I'm thinking. Sequence data coming out of Brazil is sparse, but what is available at outbreak.info suggests that Delta may be responsible for 2/3 of all cases pretty soon, and that's the threshold at which Delta surges have started in other countries.

Adding to previous forecast: As Brazil's Delta peak will likely be lower than the UK's peak (in relative terms), I think the total has a greater chance of being in bin 2 than 3.

I was far too optimistic that cases could stay in bin 1. Delta will probably cause ~2/3 of all new cases in ~1 to 3 weeks, much sooner than I was initially thinking (thanks to @paulm for making me think about this more), and cases have tended to rise once that threshold is reached. 19.69M total as of July 26, and cases at ~45k/day. Suppose cases continue to fall for another week or so, then plateau for 1 to 2 weeks, then rise. Say, 0.7M cases added in the next 2.5 weeks to Aug. 12. Then 3 months to Nov. 12. How big of a spike will Delta cause in a country that has had almost no mitigation and has a low percentage of the population fully vaccinated, nearly half of which were with a vaccine with low efficacy against infection? If cases rise as steeply as they did in the fall in Brazil, then 3.05M cases could be added in 7 weeks, to reach 19.69M + 0.7M + 3.05M = 23.4M by Sept. 30, with 6 weeks to go. But, if the UK is any guide, that high of a peak may not be reached in Brazil; the UK seems to have reached their Delta peak at ~80% of their fall/winter max. This has probably coincided with close to 100% of the population having developed antibodies to Covid (through vaccination or infection):
https://twitter.com/theosanderson/status/1418224366291013652
So, suppose that Brazil does the same. Suppose they reach ~62k/day. Then they might add 1.75M by mid September, to reach ~22.1M by then. Then a symmetric decline could follow, adding another ~1.75M by mid October, to reach 23.9M by then. Another ~0.8M could be added in the remaining 4 weeks to reach a total of 24.7M (with giant error bars).
It's also quite possible that a Delta peak in the spring in Brazil could be even lower than ~62k. Spread was slowed in the UK by many restrictions over the course of the pandemic, albeit much less than in many other countries. Brazil had far fewer restrictions than even the UK, from what I can tell. Brazil may end up with a much lower Delta peak. Update 7/27: I've learned that the UK coming off its Delta peak (so far) coincided with schools letting out. In Brazil, winter break is in July. For the remainder of the forecast period, kids will be in school.

I'm not sure to what extent due to marginal sequencing data, but I expect this to be reflected in a slowing decline of cases there shortly, and gradually affecting national numbers over the next four weeks with fluctuations across different regions. The relatively high antibody levels and herd immunity should prevent sharp increases after that but low vaccination levels will also hamper the continuing downward trend.

Updating to slightly increase the weight on bin 1. The decline has continued to be relatively steep. So, I'll forecast a total of at most ~1.05M more over the next 5 to 7 weeks, for a total of <=~20.47M, followed by a plateau of 2 to 4 weeks, adding 0.14M to 0.84M to reach <=~20.6M to 21.3M, followed by an increase in cases starting sometime between mid September and mid October, adding up to ~1.0M to reach <=~21.6M to 22.3M (or perhaps a bit more, depending on when cases start trending up again) by the end of the forecast.

Brazilians are a people with a culture of vaccination, although the president is preaching in the opposite direction and some of his supporters are not joining the campaign, the majority of the population is.

For the last Brazil question four months ago, the forecast was more of the same at 55K/day. I think herd immunity and low vaccinations will be slightly on the back foot against this variant and can't see the 7 day av. drop much past 25-30K before a plateau. 
Forecast 22-23.5M, but I hope it's lower for their sakes.

Delta variant being detected

19.3M as of July 17. 7 day avg ~41k and trending downward. ~44% have 1st dose (92.2M), 16% have 2nd, so vaccinations are becoming a factor in slowing spread. 7 day avg has hovered around 1.5M for 1st dose, ~500k for second. Combined with the relatively high number already exposed I wouldn't be surprised to see the daily spread continue to slow (finally). Moving average has been dropping almost 1k/day over the last month. Lets say it averages ~33k/day over the next month and vaccinations remain steady, that's 20.3M mid-august and ~55% first dosed. Then close to 20k/day for the next month, so ~21M mid-sept and >60% 1st dosed. Shy of a new variant that breaks the trend I'm not seeing it over 22M on Nov 12. That said, as @belikewater notes (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1308857), Delta isn't a factor there yet, so it's possible the trend could be wrecked in a bad way. I suspect the true number of infections has been much higher than reported, so hopefully there's more herd immunity than we can account for. Hopefully...

The winter wave in Brazil seems to be waning in July, much as the winter wave in the Northern Hemisphere started to wane in January. The peak this year is a bit earlier than last year's peak, though, and I'm not sure whether this is due to fewer susceptibles around, more precautions, or both. I think we can expect cases to continue to decline overall for a while now. But Delta has yet to hit. Delta is present in Brazil but represents <0.5% of all sequences in the past 60 days. Its frequency seems to be rising in the small numbers of recent samples. It's hard to say what its current frequency in Brazil is, but I'll say it's in the ballpark of 2%. If other countries offer any guide, cases won't start to increase until Delta cases are approximately 2/3 of new cases. In the US, Delta went from approximately 2% to 2/3 of all cases in a bit over 2 months. In the UK, the same transition happened over about 6 weeks. So, perhaps cases will continue to decline in Brazil over the next almost 5 to 7 weeks, then plateau for 2 to 4 weeks, and then start rising again somewhere around mid September to early October. So, I will estimate that ~1.9M or fewer cases will be added by late August or early September, cases will plateau around 10k-20k starting somewhere around late August or early September (plus or minus a few weeks), adding 0.1M to 0.6M, and then cases will start to increase again sometime between mid September to mid October. It's possible that Brazil's population has more immunity to the virus than elsewhere because restrictions have been so lacking, so it's possible that the rise there won't be as steep as in the UK and the US. The main vaccine they're using there is not the most effective, but it helps, too. The total is currently 19.26M. Before a rise in cases, I'll expect in the ballpark of 1.5 to 2.5M cases to be added to the total. Once cases start rising, I'd expect in the ballpark of 1.0M to be added. So, with giant error bars, I'll expect 2.5M to 3.5M cases to be added as of Nov. 12, for a total of 21.8M to 22.8M. The total could be lower if the decline is steep over the next month or so, as it has been. So, I'm concentrating my forecast on the lower bins. Update 7/19: The consensus has shifted towards the second bin, but I still think there's a substantial chance of the first bin, especially if the current decline continues to be steeper than the decline last winter and spring (in Brazil). Will watch and wait.
